required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Post-licensure Safety Surveillance Study of Menactra Vaccine When Administered As a 2-dose Schedule to Children
clinical_study.official_title: Post-licensure Safety Surveillance Study of Menactra® Vaccine When Administered As a 2-dose Schedule to Children 9 Months Through 23 Months of Age.

brief_summary.textblock:
This is a passive-surveillance study that will accrue subjects for surveillance. For each accrued subject, surveillance for outcomes will continue for six months following the first dose. If a second dose is given within that time, then surveillance will be continued for six months following the second dose.
Observational Objective:
- To describe and characterize adverse events occurring after vaccination with Menactra vaccine.

detailed_description.textblock:
The study will be carried out in collaboration with the Kaiser Permanente Medical Care Program (KPMCP) under the direction of the Kaiser Permanente Vaccine Study Center (KPVSC). KPMCP is a closed-panel healthcare organization that maintains comprehensive encounter databases that capture all medical care received by enrollees.
Vaccination will be according to routine clinical practice. Vaccination databases will be reviewed to identify eligible persons receiving Menactra vaccine within the KPMCP system.

primary_outcome.measure: Rates of Safety Outcomes at Days 0-30 vs Days 31-75 After Menactra Vaccine - Emergency Room Database.
primary_outcome.description: Incidence rates for each event were calculated as the number of events divided by person-time and expressed as events per 1,000 person-months in each comparison widow. The risk window was Days 0-30 following vaccination; the control window was Days 31-75 post-vaccination.

other_outcome.measure: Rates of Safety Outcomes at Days 0-30 vs Days 31-75 After Menactra Vaccine - Hospital Database.
other_outcome.description: Incidence rates for identified events were to be calculated as the number of events divided by person-time and expressed as events per 1,000 person-months in each comparison widow. The risk window was Days 0-30 following vaccination; the control window was Days 31-75 post-vaccination. Note: No events were identified in the hospital database.

other_outcome.measure: Rates of Safety Outcomes at Days 0-30 vs Days 31-75 After Menactra Vaccine - Clinic Database.
other_outcome.description: Incidence rates for pre-specified events were to be calculated as the number of events divided by person-time and expressed as events per 1,000 person-months in each comparison widow. The risk window was Days 0-30 following vaccination; the control window was Days 31-75 post-vaccination. Pre-specified neurological conditions, hypersensitivity reactions, and new-onset autoimmune disease were selected for monitoring in the clinical database. Note: None of these events were identified in the clinic database.

arm_group.description: Participants must have received Menactra Vaccine according to routine clinical practice.

intervention.intervention_name: Menactra®: Meningococcal Polysaccharide Diphtheria Toxoid Conjugate

study_pop.textblock: Participants at age 9 to 23 months at the time of receipt of the first dose of Menactra vaccine according to routine clinical practice during the study period.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age 9 to 23 months at the time of receipt of the first dose of Menactra vaccine during the study period.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Study participant accrual occurred from 16 June 2011 through 20 June 2014.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Databases of Kaiser Permanente in Northern California (KPNC) were reviewed to describe and characterize adverse events occurring after use of Menactra vaccine in routine clinical practice. Rates of events occurring in a risk window for participants were compared with rates of events occurring in a control window for the same participants.

group.title: Menactra Vaccine Recipients
group.description: Participants 9 months through 23 months of age receiving Menactra vaccine within the study institution following licensure of the vaccine for this age indication. KPNC databases were used; Menactra vaccine was administered according to routine clinical practice.

baseline.population: Participants age 9 months through 23 months of age receiving Menactra vaccine within the study institution following licensure of the vaccine for this age indication. KPNC databases were used; Menactra vaccine was administered according to routine clinical practice.

group.title: Menactra Vaccine Recipients
group.description: Participants 9 months through 23 months of age receiving Menactra vaccine within the study institution following licensure of the vaccine for this age indication. KPNC databases were used; Menactra vaccine was administered according to routine clinical practice.

measure.title: Seasonality
measure.description: Data represent participants receiving vaccine during time period shown. Four participants received 2 doses of Menactra; each dose is accounted for in the appropriate time period.

outcome.title: Rates of Safety Outcomes at Days 0–30 vs Days 31-75 After Menactra Vaccine - Emergency Room Database.
outcome.description: Incidence rates for each event were calculated as the number of events divided by person-time and expressed as events per 1,000 person-months in each comparison widow. The risk window was Days 0-30 following vaccination; the control window was Days 31-75 post-vaccination.
outcome.population: Eligible participants who received Menactra vaccine during the study period and captured in the KPNC databases were included in the analysis.

group.title: Menactra Vaccine Recipients
group.description: Participants 9 months through 23 months of age receiving Menactra vaccine within the study institution following licensure of the vaccine for this age indication. KPNC databases were used; Menactra vaccine was administered according to routine clinical practice.

group.title: Control Group
group.description: There was no separate control group per se. For all analyses, rates of events in a risk window for participants were compared with rates of events in a control window for the same participants.

measure.title: Rates of Safety Outcomes at Days 0–30 vs Days 31-75 After Menactra Vaccine - Emergency Room Database.
measure.description: Incidence rates for each event were calculated as the number of events divided by person-time and expressed as events per 1,000 person-months in each comparison widow. The risk window was Days 0-30 following vaccination; the control window was Days 31-75 post-vaccination.
measure.population: Eligible participants who received Menactra vaccine during the study period and captured in the KPNC databases were included in the analysis.

outcome.title: Rates of Safety Outcomes at Days 0–30 vs Days 31-75 After Menactra Vaccine - Hospital Database.
outcome.description: Incidence rates for identified events were to be calculated as the number of events divided by person-time and expressed as events per 1,000 person-months in each comparison widow. The risk window was Days 0-30 following vaccination; the control window was Days 31-75 post-vaccination. Note: No events were identified in the hospital database.
outcome.population: All participants who received Menactra vaccine during the study period and captured in the KPNC databases were included in the analysis.

reported_events.time_frame: Surveillance period for adverse events was from the day of vaccination to 6 months post-final vaccination, an average of 6 months.

group.title: Menactra Vaccine Recipients
group.description: Participants who received Menactra vaccine during the study period from the Kaiser Permanente databases.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: Sponsor must have the opportunity to review at least 60 days prior to submission for publication or presentation. If review indicates that potentially patentable subject matter would be disclosed, publication or public disclosure may be delayed for a maximum of an additional 60 days to allow for filing the necessary patent applications.
